H0.text: Light is the product of the fire that is in the form of electromagnetic waves for campers sitting around a campfire outside their tent.

H1.text: Smoke is the product of the campfire that is in the form of electromagnetic waves, while campers sit around the fire outside their tent.

H2.text: Sound is the product of the campfire that is in the form of electromagnetic waves for campers sitting around the fire outside their tent.

H3.text: Water vapor is the product of the campfire that takes the form of electromagnetic waves for campers sitting around a fire outside their tent.

A4.text: A common thermal light source in history is the glowing solid particles in flames, but these also emit most of their radiation in the infrared and only a fraction in the visible spectrum.

A5.text: With the development of electric lights and power systems, electric lighting has effectively replaced firelight.

A6.text: Black-body radiation is emitted from soot, gas, and fuel particles, though the soot particles are too small to behave like perfect blackbodies.

A7.text: Fire is a chemical process in which a fuel and an oxidizing agent react, yielding carbon dioxide and water.
